courseTitle: DNA, RNA, and the Central Dogma

pageData.titleName2: DNA, RNA, and the Central Dogma

pageData.text: In this laboratory investigation, students explore the basic structure of —represented with pop beads—as they model the process of . Then, students will investigate the processing of genetic information via and . Finally, students examine the processes and consequences of genetic mutations.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or cell phone with a camera

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Activity 1: DNA Structure – 25 minutes 
Activity 2: DNA Replication – 30 minutes  
Activity 3: Transcription – 25 minutes 
Activity 4: Translation – 10 minutes 
Activity 5: Mutation – 10 minutes
pageData.desc:
Preparation for Each Dissection – 5–10 minutes 
Activity 1: Mammalian Heart Dissection – 40 minutes 
Activity 2: Mammalian Kidney Dissection – 20 minutes 
Activity 3: Mammalian Brain Dissection – 30 minutes 
Activity 4: Mammalian Eye Dissection – 40 minutes

pageData.text: The activities are designed to be conducted in order.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: DNA, RNA, and the Central Dogma

text: Describe the general structure of DNA.
Design a model showing the replication of DNA.
Create models demonstrating and .
Identify causes of genetic mutations and their effect on protein synthesis.

pageData.text: Genetic disorders occur when a mutation occurs in a <button class=glossary-text>gene</button>. Many of these disorders are inherited, such as sickle-cell or hemophilia. Exposure to chemicals, pollutants, and radiation can also cause genetic mutations that are associated with chronic diseases and cancer. However, mutations are not always bad.

One of the genes involved in maintaining bone density in human beings is called low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 5 (LRP5). Certain mutations impair the function of LRP5 and are associated with osteoporosis (low bone density), but a different kind of mutation in LRP5 can increase its function and result in higher levels of bone density. This mutation was discovered after a young person was in a terrible car accident but walked away from it. After the crash, researchers studied the family and discovered that no one in the family had ever broken a bone and had much higher-than-average bone density. The only negative side effect appears to be that some of the family members with the mutation have boney growths in the roof of their mouths1. Researchers are currently working on gene therapies that may enhance the function of LRP5 and prevent osteoporosis.1Boyden, L. M., Mao, J., Belsky, J., Mitzner, L., Farhi, A., Mitnick, M. A., Wu, D., Insogna, K., & Lifton, R. P. (2002). High bone density due to a mutation in LDL-receptor-related protein 5. The New England journal of medicine, 346(20), 1513–1521. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa013444

pageData.altText: A medical illustration of a bone cross section.
pageData.desc: A medical illustration of a bone cross section.

pageData.text: stores the genetic information in all living cells. The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the order of their DNA molecules. DNA takes the form of a double helix (resembling a twisted ladder). A DNA molecule has two complementary strands made up of nitrogenous bases, sugars (represented by "S" in Figure 1), and phosphates (represented by “P” in Figure 1). The four bases in DNA are the two purines, and , and the two pyrimidines, and . These bases follow the base-pairing rules: adenine and thymine always pair together with two hydrogen bonds, and guanine and cytosine always pair together with three hydrogen bonds (Figure 1).

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

pageData.text: DNA contains the five-carbon sugar deoxyribose. RNA contains the five-carbon sugar ribose. Understanding how the carbons within these sugar molecules are numbered is essential to understanding nucleic acid formation and orientation. Each carbon is assigned a number, 1–5. Deoxyribose is shown in Figure 2, with each carbon numbered.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Deoxyribose is a five-membered ring. One oxygen atom and four carbon atoms make up the ring. The carbon atoms are numbered clockwise from the oxygen atom. Carbons one prime, two prime, three prime, and four prime make up the rest of the ring. Carbon five prime extends from carbon four prime, and is not part of the ring. Each carbon atom, except for carbon two prime, has an attached O H group.

pageData.text: In a <button class=glossary-text>nucleotide</button>, the phosphate group is bound to the 5' (pronounced “five prime”) carbon of the sugar molecule, and the nitrogenous base is bound to the 1' carbon of the sugar molecule. To form nucleic acid chains, nucleotides form covalent bonds between the phosphate group of one nucleotide and the 3' carbon of the sugar molecule of another nucleotide. This forms the phosphate-sugar backbone of a nucleic acid strand. In DNA, the two oppositely aligned backbone strands are described as being antiparallel. At the end, or terminus, of a double- stranded DNA molecule, one strand will expose its 5' phosphate end and the other will expose its 3' unbound hydroxyl (-OH) end.

pageData.question: In DNA, which of the following base pairs is most likely to form?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In DNA, the nucleotide bases follow the base-pairing rules: adenine (A) and thymine (T) always pair together with two hydrogen bonds, and guanine (G) and cytosine (C) always pair together with three hydrogen bonds.

pageData.question: Which of the following does the shape of a DNA double helix resemble?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A double helix resembles a twisted ladder.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the nucleotide order of their DNA molecules. In multicellular organisms (eukaryotes), DNA is arranged in the form of a double helix, with two complementary strands made up of nucleotide bases, sugars, and phosphates. The four nucleic acids found in DNA are the two purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), and the two pyrimidines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The inheritable characteristics and processes of living organisms are encoded within the nucleotide order of their DNA molecules. In multicellular organisms (eukaryotes), DNA is arranged in the form of a double helix, with two complementary strands made up of nucleotide bases, sugars, and phosphates. The four nucleic acids found in DNA are the two purines, adenine (A) and guanine (G), and the two pyrimidines, cytosine (C) and thymine (T).

pageData.subTitle: DNA Replication
pageData.text: Because DNA is the carrier of genetic information, it is essential that the sequence be correctly duplicated from one cell division to the next. This process is known as . During the process of replication, the two complementary strands of DNA are partly denatured, or separated, by the action of proteins called . Each DNA strand then utilizes special enzymes to complete the synthesis of a complementary strand by base pairing.

The process of replication is aided by , or . RNA is similar to DNA but differs in several important ways. RNA contains ribose, whereas DNA contains deoxyribose. As mentioned previously, eukaryotic DNA is double stranded, in the form of a helix, whereas RNA is single stranded. Furthermore, the nitrogenous base , which is found in DNA, is replaced with in RNA strands. Uracil pairs with .

For replication to begin in the eukaryotic cell, the DNA molecule must unwind into two single-stranded templates that will serve as the sequential patterns for the new replica strands of . Enzymes, called , nick the strand and provide an opening for unwinding to occur at hundreds of points along the chromosome, called . Another enzyme present in the nuclear material, , unwinds the double helix by breaking the hydrogen bonds between nitrogenous bases. Binding proteins attach to the “unzipped” strands to keep them from rebinding.

Both nucleotide chains serve as templates for but they are not processed the same way. Recall that the strands are antiparallel. The strand that is oriented in the 5' to 3' direction is called the . The strand oriented in the 3' to 5' direction is called the .

The DNA polymerase enzymes that assist in synthesizing the new DNA strand only make DNA in the 5' to 3' direction. For the leading strand, an enzyme complex with DNA polymerase adds complementary nucleotides to the template strand in the 5' to 3' direction and continues to do so as the double strands unzip.

For the lagging strand, DNA synthesis is more complicated. DNA polymerase cannot initiate DNA synthesis without a phosphate to bind to; however, RNA polymerase can. Primase initiates the addition of the first RNA, and RNA polymerase adds about 10 RNA bases to the exposed 3' portion of the lagging strand. This RNA portion is called a . DNA polymerase then takes over, adding DNA bases following the primer.

Replication on the occurs in short, discontinuous segments in the opposite direction of the . Continuous addition of RNA and short DNA segments of the lagging strand are required to keep pace with the synthesis of the leading strand. Thus, only a limited stretch of DNA (an , named for its discoverer) can be synthesized from the lagging strand at one time.

RNA primer segments must be excised, as they are not suitable long-term substitutes for DNA <button class=glossary-text>nucleotides</button> in the genetic code. The phosphate bonds between the DNA sugar and the RNA sugar are broken to remove the RNA primer, and DNA polymerase brings in the DNA nucleotides that add on at the 3' end of the preceding sugar to fill the gap. During <button class=glossary-text>DNA replication,</button> polymerization begins at the open 3' end of the nucleotide chain.

To summarize DNA replication, the two strands of DNA separate. Each strand serves as a template to which new complementary bases are added. A host of enzymes, principally DNA polymerases, add nucleotides to the template following base pairing rules, resulting in two newly synthesized strands of DNA, each bound to the original template.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription

pageData.subTitle: Transcription
pageData.text: RNA is the vehicle through which the genetic code is translated into the proteins that perform all of life’s functions. An RNA , like a DNA nucleotide, contains inorganic phosphate group(s), a sugar, and a nitrogenous base. However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base does not occur. Instead, is complemented by in RNA. RNA molecules are able to bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell are able to read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called .

Transcription begins in a process called when RNA polymerase binds to a site with a specific DNA sequence, called a . In eukaryotic cells, other molecules, called “transcription factors,” also play a role in initiating the process of RNA synthesis. Once RNA polymerase binds to the DNA, the double strand is unwound and separated.

<button class=glossary-text>Elongation</button> occurs next, where the enzyme travels along one of the DNA strands, called the template, or antisense strand, in the 3' to 5' direction. As it travels, the enzyme reads the  DNA sequence and builds a complementary strand of RNA. This RNA strand is generated from 5' to 3'.
The RNA polymerase eventually falls off in a process called , where the two DNA strands reconnect, and the complementary RNA sequence is free within the nucleus.
There are three major types of RNA generated by transcription: ribosomal (rRNA), messenger (mRNA), and transfer (tRNA).

Ribosomal RNA combines with proteins to form complexes called . Each ribosome has two sites: amino acyl (A site) and peptidyl (P site). The ribosome functions in stabilizing and moving various members of the protein synthesis apparatus at appropriate times within the cytoplasm. Messenger RNA provides the instructions for protein synthesis based on the DNA sequence.

Transfer RNA interacts with ribosomes and acts as a carrier molecule, transferring specific amino acids designated by the mRNA sequences to an amino acid chain. The tRNA folds in such a way that its anticodon (3' nucleotide sequence) can bind with a complementary codon on the mRNA. At the 3' end of the tRNA sequence, there is a site for a specific amino acid to bind.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the stages of transcription?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Transcription goes through the stages of initiation (RNA polymerase binds to the DNA), elongation (RNA polymerase reads and DNA and synthesis an RNA sequence), and termination (RNA polymerase releases the DNA and the new RNA molecule is complete).

pageData.question: What is one way that DNA is different from RNA?

options.text: DNA has thymine and RNA has uracil.
DNA has ribose and RNA has deoxyribose.
DNA has more enzymes than RNA.
DNA has adenine-thymine base pairing and RNA has adenine-adenine base pairing.
DNA is synthesized on the leading strand and RNA is synthesized on the lagging strand.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: DNA has the nucleotide thymine (T), which is not found in RNA. RNA has the nucleotide uracil (U), which is not found in DNA.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An RNA nucleotide, like a DNA nucleotide, contains inorganic phosphate group(s), sugar, and a nitrogenous base. However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base thymine does not occur. Instead, adenine is complemented by uracil in RNA. RNA molecules can bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell can read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called transcription, which consists of three stages: initiation (when RNA polymerase binds to the DNA and separates its strands), elongation (when RNA polymerase reads the DNA sequence and builds a complimentary strand of RNA), and termination (when RNA polymerase falls off the DNA, its strands reconnect, and the new RNA is free within the nucleus).

img.alt: Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription

However, the sugar in RNA is ribose, and the nitrogenous base thymine does not occur. Instead, adenine is complemented by uracil in RNA. RNA molecules can bind together to make long strands. The order of nucleotides in an RNA sequence is determined by the order of nucleotides in DNA. Enzymes in the cell can read the order of nucleotides in the DNA and match complementary RNA bases to the DNA sequence. This process is called transcription, which consists of three stages: initiation (when RNA polymerase binds to the DNA and separates its strands), elongation (when RNA polymerase reads the DNA sequence and builds a complimentary strand of RNA), and termination (when RNA polymerase falls off the DNA, its strands reconnect, and the new RNA is free within the nucleus).

img.alt: Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription

pageData.subTitle: Translation and Protein Synthesis
pageData.text: Messenger RNA and transfer RNA work together to position amino acids at the <button class=glossary-text>ribosome</button> for protein synthesis. The specific order of amino acids is determined by the mRNA codons; thus, the genetic code is translated into a sequence of amino acids during protein synthesis. The ribosomes take residence in the cell’s cytoplasm and function as sites for protein synthesis. Eukaryotic ribosomes have two parts, a small and a large subunit. The smaller subunit is referred to as 40 S, and the large subunit is referred to as 60 S.

The ribosomes function to stabilize and move various molecules necessary for protein synthesis at appropriate times within the cytoplasm. They also catalyze the formation of peptide bonds between amino acids to create a polypeptide chain, the primary structure of a protein.

Transfer RNA is found throughout the cytoplasm, where it reacts with activated amino acids. Activation consists of an enzyme-mediated reaction between an amino acid and ATP. The enzymes involved in this reaction recognize specific amino acids and specific tRNA molecules. For example, the activating enzyme for glycine will bind glycine only to glycine-specific tRNA molecules. The amino acid-tRNA complex reaches a ribosome by diffusion. The tRNA binds to a single amino acid that enters the aminoacyl site. If the single amino acid is a match with the <button class=glossary-text>nucleotides</button> in the mRNA strand, then the tRNA binds to the aminoacyl site. If the three nucleotides are not complementary, the tRNA is rejected.

Activation of the tRNA occurs when an enzyme called aminoacyl-tRNA synthase brings the free-floating amino acid and tRNA together. With energy input from ATP, the amino acid binds to the tRNA. At this point, the tRNA is considered to be activated.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Illustration of the activation of tRNA

pageData.text: As the mRNA sequence passes through the ribosomal subunits, one codon (3 <button class=glossary-text>nucleotides</button>) is read at the aminoacyl-tRNA site (A site). This codon interacts with free-floating tRNAs. When the anticodon of the specific tRNA complements the mRNA codon, then the tRNA is transferred to the peptidyl-tRNA site (P site) and the associated amino acid is added to the chain to build a polypeptide, or protein. Energy is required for many of the reactions, and it is provided by the hydrolysis of GTP, a molecule similar to ATP.

When this sequence is translated into a protein, a matching amino acid is selected for each codon in the sequence. The codons do not start at a random site; the first mRNA codon is always AUG, or the amino acid, methionine. Once the “Start” (AUG) codon is located, the rest of the codons will follow, three nucleotides at a time. This process is known as .

Once the initiator-tRNA anticodon binds to the complementary mRNA sequence in the P site, initiation factors help the large ribosomal subunit attach to the complex. The initial methionine is located on one end of the polypeptide, which is called the N-terminus. The opposite end of the polypeptide is called the C-terminus.

If there is a tRNA already in the P site, its amino acid chain is transferred to the end of the amino acid in the A site. A peptide bond is formed by a reaction catalyzed by the large subunit of the . Next, the ribosome moves the tRNA from the A site to the P site. The former P site tRNA is released from the ribosome without its amino acid. The ribosome moves the mRNA so that a new codon is above the A site. This process is known as .

is when the mRNA stop sequence moves into the A site. A protein called a release factor binds in the place of a tRNA and breaks the bond between the tRNA and the polypeptide. Finally, the ribosomal subunits separate and the polypeptide is freed. There are three “stop” codons, which are the combinations of that signal the replication enzymes to halt (Figure 5).

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Three stop codons terminating translation

pageData.subTitle: Mutations
pageData.text: With advancements in biotechnology, scientists now rely on DNA similarities to determine relationships between groups of organisms. Species that have similar DNA sequences are thought to have evolved from a common ancestor.

Organisms that are more distantly related have, over time, accumulated more differences in their DNA sequences. The difference between DNA sequences, both within a species and across species, is called . The mechanism of variation is mutation, a change in DNA sequence. Harmful mutations that hinder an organism’s fitness (its ability to survive and reproduce) are less likely to be passed on to the next generation.

Mutations that generate advantages for an organism may be selected by natural selection, the driving force of evolution. Many types of mutations exist (), including (s), , , and . A substitution is the replacement of one base with another. Insertion occurs when nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence. Deletion occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence.

Mutations can occur because of mistakes during or as a result of environmental influences such as UV radiation or chemical exposure. Scientists do not understand all of the factors that influence the rate of mutation. However, it is known that because of the redundancy of the genetic code, not all mutations result in a phenotypic change; these unexpressed mutations are called . Multiple combinations of RNA nucleotides code for the same amino acid. If a mutation occurs but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid during , the protein will likely function properly. A mutation that causes one amino acid in the protein sequence to change is referred to as a . A mutation that leads to a stop signal in an inappropriate place is called a . If the translational enzymes are signaled to stop before the protein is complete, the protein is unlikely to function at all. There may be other variables that affect the success of protein synthesis, such as posttranslational modifications, but these are beyond the scope of this discussion.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: An illustration of examples of different types of mutations; a mutagenic event, a deletion, an insertion, and a substitution

pageData.question: A substitution mutation occurs in a gene, but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid as the original codon. Which of the following best describes how this mutation impacts the protein synthesized from this mutated gene?

options.text: The protein would most likely function properly.
The protein would most likely be duplicated.
The protein would most likely be larger.
The protein would most likely not be translated.
The protein would most likely have a new function.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If a substitution mutation occurs but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid during translation, the protein will likely function properly.

pageData.question: Which of the following is true about mutation?

options.text: A mutation does not necessarily result in a phenotypic change.
A mutation results in a phenotypic change.
Mutations are always caused by misfolded proteins.
Mutations do not affect start and stop codons.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Because of the redundancy of the genetic code, not all mutations result in a phenotypic change; these unexpressed mutations are called silent mutations.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Species that have similar DNA sequences are thought to have evolved from a common ancestor. Organisms that are more distantly related have, over time, accumulated more differences in their DNA sequences. The difference between DNA sequences, both within a species and across species, is called genetic variation. Mutations that generate advantages for an organism may be selected by natural selection, the driving force of evolution. Many types of mutations exist, including substitutions, insertions, deletions, and gene duplications. A mutation that causes one amino acid in the protein sequence to change is referred to as a missense mutation. A mutation that leads to a stop signal in an inappropriate place is called a nonsense mutation. If a point mutation occurs but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid during translation, the protein will likely function properly.

img.alt: Figure 6: An illustration of examples of different types of mutations; a mutagenic event, a deletion, an insertion, and a substitution

Mutations that generate advantages for an organism may be selected by natural selection, the driving force of evolution. Many types of mutations exist, including substitutions, insertions, deletions, and gene duplications. A mutation that causes one amino acid in the protein sequence to change is referred to as a missense mutation. A mutation that leads to a stop signal in an inappropriate place is called a nonsense mutation. If a point mutation occurs but the resulting codon codes for the same amino acid during translation, the protein will likely function properly.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 1-2 of this investigation. In Activity 1, you will build DNA nucleotides from pop beads and construct a single strand of DNA from them. Next, you will complete the model to create double-stranded DNA. Then, you will twist the model into a double helix and save it. In Activity 2, you will build RNA nucleotides for primers before unwinding and unpairing half of the DNA model. Next, you will add complementary DNA nucleotides to the leading strand. Then, construct an RNA primer and add it to the lagging strand. Next, add complementary DNA nucleotides to the lagging strand and replace the RNA primer with nucleotides. You will repeat this process until the entire DNA model has been replicated. Finally, dismantle the models, keeping the nucleotides intact. Then continue to Activity 3.
pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 1-2 of this investigation. In Activity 1, you will build DNA nucleotides from pop beads and construct a single strand of DNA from them. Next, you will complete the model to create double-stranded DNA. Then, you will twist the model into a double helix and save it. In Activity 2, you will build RNA nucleotides for primers before unwinding and unpairing half of the DNA model. Next, you will add complementary DNA nucleotides to the leading strand. Then, construct an RNA primer and add it to the lagging strand. Next, add complementary DNA nucleotides to the lagging strand and replace the RNA primer with nucleotides. You will repeat this process until the entire DNA model has been replicated. Finally, dismantle the models, keeping the nucleotides intact. Then continue to Activity 3.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 3-5 of this investigation. After completing Activity 2, in Activity 3 you will construct a DNA strand from a given sequence. Next, add complementary RNA nucleotides to the DNA strand. Then, separate the RNA strand from the DNA strand. You will save the DNA strand as the DNA model for Activity 5, and the RNA strand as the mRNA model for Activity 4. In Activity 4, you will determine the amino acid sequence coded by the mRNA model, then dismantle the mRNA model, keeping the nucleotides intact. In Activity 5, you will construct a mutation in the DNA model, then add complementary RNA nucleotides to the DNA model. Next, you will determine the amino acid sequence coded by the RNA strand. Finally, compare the amino acid sequences from Activities 4 and 5.
pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 3-5 of this investigation. After completing Activity 2, in Activity 3 you will construct a DNA strand from a given sequence. Next, add complementary RNA nucleotides to the DNA strand. Then, separate the RNA strand from the DNA strand. You will save the DNA strand as the DNA model for Activity 5, and the RNA strand as the mRNA model for Activity 4. In Activity 4, you will determine the amino acid sequence coded by the mRNA model, then dismantle the mRNA model, keeping the nucleotides intact. In Activity 5, you will construct a mutation in the DNA model, then add complementary RNA nucleotides to the DNA model. Next, you will determine the amino acid sequence coded by the RNA strand. Finally, compare the amino acid sequences from Activities 4 and 5.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the product of transcription?

options.text: tRNA works with mRNA to position amino acids at the ribosome for protein synthesis.
tRNA transfers code from DNA to proteins.
tRNA forms part of the structure of the large ribosomal subunit.
tRNA provides the instructions for protein synthesis based on a DNA sequence.
tRNA builds a complementary strand of DNA.

assestmentData.question: What type of mutagenic event is most likely to cause a missense mutation?

options.text: They can cause irritation to the eyes or skin.

What type of bonds occur between nucleotides and phosphate groups in a nucleic acid chain?

Which of the following is most likely to cause a mutation in an organism’s DNA sequence?

options.text: an error in translation during protein synthesis

Some flashing may remain on the beads from the casting process. This can make joining the beads difficult. Lightly scraping the sides of the hole on a bead with a pair of scissors may make joining the beads together easier.
In Activity 1, you will use pop beads to create a model of double-stranded DNA with a sequence of your choosing. You will use this model in Activity 2.

Build the following by attaching a phosphate group (red bead) to the 5' position of the deoxyribose sugar (white bead) and by attaching one nitrogenous base to the 1 position of the same sugar (Figure 7).10 DNA nucleotides (orange)
10 DNA nucleotides (green)
10 DNA nucleotides (blue)
10 DNA nucleotides (yellow)

pageData.altText: Figure 7: An illustration using the different colored pop beads to show examples of a phosphate group, deoxyribose sugar and an attached nitrogenous base for each of the four nucleotides. Shown left to right: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine.

pageData.text: <span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>The white bead is deoxyribose, with the connector peg representing the 3' position and the hole opposite the peg representing the 5' position.

Construct a single-stranded polynucleotide chain by attaching the phosphate group (red bead) of one nucleotide to the 3' peg of the sugar (white bead) of another nucleotide. Use three of each DNA nucleotide in any order. The model should now consist of a single strand of 12 nucleotides.

Complete the double-stranded DNA by adding complementary bases. Use a hydrogen bond (clear connector) to link the two base pairs. Adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T), and guanine (G) pairs with cytosine (C). Remember to make the strands antiparallel. They are antiparallel if the peg of the phosphate (red bead) of one strand points in the opposite direction of the deoxyribose (white bead) peg on the other strand (Figure 8).

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A double-stranded, anti-parallel DNA model with 12 base pairs.

pageData.text: Grasp the complete DNA molecule by the base pair at each end of the double strands. Gently twist the molecule into the form of a spiraling ladder, being careful not to separate the hydrogen bonds between base pairs. This represents the double helical structure of the DNA molecule.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a picture and save the DNA molecule for the <button class=glossary-text>DNA Replication</button> activity.
In Activity 2, you will simulate the process of using the DNA model created in Activity 1.

Build the following 16 , which are each made up of three beads (Figure 9). RNA begins with a ribose sugar (pink bead) and a phosphate group (red bead) and is completed with a nitrogen base.3 nucleotides (orange)
4 nucleotides (green)
4 nucleotides (blue)
5 nucleotides (purple)

pageData.altText: Figure 9: An illustration using the different colored pop beads to show examples of a phosphate group, ribose sugar and an attached nitrogenous base for each of the four nucleotides. Shown left to right: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and uracil.

pageData.text: Twist the DNA model from Activity 1, DNA Structure, into a helix to represent a double-stranded molecule inside a cell.
Simulate the enzyme action of <button class=glossary-text>DNA helicase</button> by untwisting the DNA.

Orient the double-stranded DNA molecule on the desk so that the top strand reads 5' to 3' (red bead on the left and white bead on the right) and the bottom strand reads 3' to 5' (white bead on the left and red bead on the right).

Simulate the nicking of the strand by by breaking the first hydrogen bond between the complementary bases on the right side of the model. Continue to separate the strands from the right side of the molecule until six bases are separated (Figure 10).

pageData.altText: Figure 10: An illustration of DNA replication with two single-stranded portions of the pop beads

pageData.text: Actual DNA is much longer than 12 base pairs, so the single-stranded region that undergoes replication is typically flanked by long sections of double-stranded DNA (). At any given time during DNA synthesis, there are hundreds of replication forks along the chromosome.
Spread the two single-stranded portions approximately 30 centimeters apart. The top strand represents the , and the bottom strand represents the .

Begin to synthesize new DNA from the leading strand (top). Your hands simulate the action of DNA polymerase as complementary DNA nucleotides are added to the template strand (right to left) (Figure 11).

pageData.altText: Figure 11: Illustration of new DNA being synthesized from the leading strand

pageData.text: For the lagging strand (bottom), add three complementary RNA bases to represent the RNA <button class=glossary-text>primer</button> from left to right.
Simulate the switch to synthesis by DNA polymerase by adding complementary DNA bases following the primer for the remaining three bases.

RNA primer segments are not suitable long-term substitutes for DNA nucleotides in the genetic code. Break the phosphate bonds between the DNA sugars and the RNA sugars, and then remove all the RNA bases from the chain. Fill in the gap with DNA bases (Figure 12).

pageData.altText: Figure 12: Illustration of completion of DNA synthesis from the leading strand

pageData.text: Complete the addition of DNA bases to the leading strand for the six exposed bases.
Break the following six hydrogen bonds (connected in Figure 11) to extend the single-stranded region (broken in Figure 12).

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Repeat Steps 7 through 11 using the remaining RNA and DNA bases. You may find it useful to document steps along the way for your notes. The resulting structure should include two complete and matching models of double-stranded DNA. Take a picture of your final strands.
Note: No RNA nucleotides will be in the final replicated DNA (Figure 13).

pageData.altText: Figure 13: Two identical, double-stranded, anti-parallel DNA models each with 12 base pairs.

pageData.text: Dismantle the DNA structure while keeping each nucleotide intact.
In Activity 3, you will simulate the process of by creating an RNA model complementary to a DNA model. You will use the RNA model in Activity 4 and the DNA model in Activity 5.

Make sure the following 30 are prepared:DNA
5
3
4
3 RNA
3 Adenine
5
3 Cytosine
4 Guanine

Connect the DNA nucleotides in the following order:
3'-TAC CAC GTA GAC TGA-5'

The phosphate group of one nucleotide bonds at the 3' carbon of the adjacent nucleotide. One of the two separated strands is used as a guide to build a complementary RNA strand. In this model, only the template strand has been prepared.

Starting with the 3' end of the strand, pair each free RNA nucleotide with its DNA complement [uracil (U) complements adenine (A) in RNA]. This addition is catalyzed by RNA polymerase. Notice that the RNA strand is being synthesized in the 5' to 3' direction.
Record the complementary DNA and RNA sequences from 5' to 3' in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Separate the DNA and RNA strands. Once RNA is formed, it is released from DNA and goes to other parts of the cell. Take a picture of the final RNA strand.
Save the final RNA strand for use in Activity 4. Save the DNA sequence for use in Activity 5.
In Activity 4, you will simulate the process of using the RNA model created in Activity 3 and a codon chart to determine the proper sequence of amino acids.
Assuming the modeled RNA strand is mRNA, use Table 1, the “mRNA Codons for Amino Acids,” to determine which three amino acids are encoded on the mRNA strand.

The codons in Table 1 are written in three-letter combinations read in the 5' to 3' direction. The base-pair combinations for each of the 20 essential amino acids are followed by the name of the amino acid and (in parentheses) its three-letter and one-letter abbreviations. For this sequence, assume that the first three <button class=glossary-text>nucleotides</button> represent the first codon.
Record the amino acid sequence in Data Table 2. Dismantle the mRNA structure while keeping each nucleotide intact.
In Activity 5, you will create a mutation in the DNA model from Activity 3. You will then repeat the process of from Activity 3 and from Activity 4 to evaluate the new sequence of amino acids.

Assume a mistake occurs during . Build the leading DNA strand, if it has not been prepared already.
TACCACGTAGACTGA
Generate a , , or mutation in the . For example, to simulate a substitution, remove one and replace it with a .
Write the mutated DNA sequence and circle the modified in Data Table 3.
Link the complementary RNA nucleotides to the modified sequence. Disassemble some DNA molecule beads to make additional RNA nucleotides, if necessary.
Write the RNA sequence in Data Table 3.
Use the “mRNA Codons for Amino Acids” chart in to match the new codons with their amino acids. Write the amino acid sequence in Data Table 3.

text: Put all beads back in the lab bag.
Clean up your work area, making sure no spare beads are left out.

pageData.title: Questions
text: Explain the differences between the original amino acid sequence in the exercise and the one coded for by the mutated DNA/RNA.
Will the protein that was translated from the mutated DNA function with the mutation that was generated? Explain your reasoning.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of a DNA molecule shows two strands twisted around each other. Each strand is an alternating sequence of sugars and phosphate groups, with a base attached to each sugar. The bases orient toward each other and form specific pairs. A pairs with T, and G pairs with C.

Figure 2: Deoxyribose is a five-membered ring. One oxygen atom and four carbon atoms make up the ring. The carbon atoms are numbered clockwise from the oxygen atom. Carbons one prime, two prime, three prime, and four prime make up the rest of the ring. Carbon five prime extends from carbon four prime, and is not part of the ring. Each carbon atom, except for carbon two prime, has an attached O H group.
Figure 3: An illustration of RNA transcription
Figure 4: Illustration of the activation of tRNA
Figure 5: Three stop codons terminating translation
Figure 6: An illustration of examples of different types of mutations; a mutagenic event, a deletion, an insertion, and a substitution

A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 1-2 of this investigation. In Activity 1, you will build DNA nucleotides from pop beads and construct a single strand of DNA from them. Next, you will complete the model to create double-stranded DNA. Then, you will twist the model into a double helix and save it. In Activity 2, you will build RNA nucleotides for primers before unwinding and unpairing half of the DNA model. Next, you will add complementary DNA nucleotides to the leading strand. Then, construct an RNA primer and add it to the lagging strand. Next, add complementary DNA nucleotides to the lagging strand and replace the RNA primer with nucleotides. You will repeat this process until the entire DNA model has been replicated. Finally, dismantle the models, keeping the nucleotides intact. Then continue to Activity 3.

A map describing the procedural workflow for Activities 3-5 of this investigation. After completing Activity 2, in Activity 3 you will construct a DNA strand from a given sequence. Next, add complementary RNA nucleotides to the DNA strand. Then, separate the RNA strand from the DNA strand. You will save the DNA strand as the DNA model for Activity 5, and the RNA strand as the mRNA model for Activity 4. In Activity 4, you will determine the amino acid sequence coded by the mRNA model, then dismantle the mRNA model, keeping the nucleotides intact. In Activity 5, you will construct a mutation in the DNA model, then add complementary RNA nucleotides to the DNA model. Next, you will determine the amino acid sequence coded by the RNA strand. Finally, compare the amino acid sequences from Activities 4 and 5.

Figure 7: An illustration using the different colored pop beads to show examples of a phosphate group, deoxyribose sugar and an attached nitrogenous base for each of the four nucleotides. Shown left to right: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine.
Figure 8: A double-stranded, anti-parallel DNA model with 12 base pairs.
pageData.content: Figure 8. Proper orientation of DNA model

pageData.altText: Figure 9: An illustration using the different colored pop beads to show examples of a phosphate group, ribose sugar and an attached nitrogenous base for each of the four nucleotides. Shown left to right: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and uracil.
Figure 10: An illustration of DNA replication with two single-stranded portions of the pop beads
pageData.content: Figure 10. Model of DNA replication fork

pageData.altText: Figure 11: Illustration of new DNA being synthesized from the leading strand
Figure 12: Illustration of completion of DNA synthesis from the leading strand
Figure 13: Two identical, double-stranded, anti-parallel DNA models each with 12 base pairs.
pageData.content: Figure 13. Final model of DNA replication
Table 1. mRNA Codons for Amino Acids
pageData.title:
Table 1.
mRNA Codons for Amino Acids

data.title: Adenine (A)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids; it is classified as a purine and it pairs with thymine (T) in DNA and uracil (U) in RNA

data.title: Cytosine (C)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids; it is classified as a pyrimidine and it pairs with guanine (G)

data.title: Deletion
data.content: A type of mutation that occurs when nucleotides are omitted from a DNA sequence

data.title: Deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)
data.content: A type of nucleic acid made up of nucleotide monomers containing deoxyribose sugar; it stores the genetic information of an organism

data.title: DNA helicase
data.content: An enzyme that partly denatures (separates) DNA's double strand during DNA replication

data.title: DNA replication
data.content: The process of duplicating DNA during cell division

data.title: Duplication
data.content: A mutation in which one or more copies of a DNA segment is produced; it can be as small as just a few bases or as large as a major chromosomal region

data.title: Elongation
data.content: The process of an enzyme reading a DNA sequence and building a complementary strand of RNA during transcription; it is also the process of a ribosome reading an mRNA sequence and building a complementary sequence of amino acids during translation

data.title: Endonuclease
data.content: An enzyme which cleaves the hydrogen bonds of a polynucleotide chain which provides an opening for unwinding of the molecule to occur

data.title: Gene
data.content: A specific sequence of nucleotides, the order of which determines the amino acid sequence of a protein.

data.title: Genetic variation
data.content: Differences between DNA sequences within a species and across species

data.title: Guanine (G)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids; it is classified as a purine and pairs with cytosine (C)

data.title: Initiation
data.content: The process of RNA polymerase binding to a site with a specific DNA sequence to start transcription; also the process of a ribosome identifying and binding to the AUG codon of an mRNA strand to start translation

data.title: Insertion
data.content: A mutation in which nucleotides are added into a DNA sequence

data.title: Lagging strand
data.content: During DNA replication it is the strand that is oriented in the 3' to 5' direction

data.title: Leading strand
data.content: During DNA replication it is the strand that is oriented in the 5' to 3' direction

data.title: Missense mutation
data.content: A mutation in which one amino acid in the protein sequence is changed to a different amino acid

data.title: Nonsense mutation
data.content: A mutation that leads to a stop signal in an inappropriate place in the mRNA sequence

data.title: Nucleotide
data.content: The monomer of nucleic acids; it consists of a pentose (five-carbon) sugar, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base

data.title: Okazaki fragment
data.content: Short sections of DNA formed because of discontinuous synthesis of the lagging strand during DNA replication

data.title: Primer
data.content: A short nucleic acid sequence that provides a starting point for nucleic acid synthesis

data.title: Promoter
data.content: A region of DNA upstream of a gene where relevant proteins bind to initiate transcription

data.title: Replication fork
data.content: A region where the double helix has been unwound and separated, and DNA replication occurs

data.title: Ribonucleic acid (RNA)
data.content: A type of nucleic acid that is single-stranded and involved in protein synthesis; it is made up nucleotide monomers containing ribose sugar

data.title: Ribosome
data.content: A complex molecular machine that translates mRNA molecules to produce polypeptides (amino acid sequences)

data.title: Silent mutation
data.content: A mutation that does not result in a phenotypic change in the organism

data.title: Substitution
data.content: A mutation in which one nucleotide base is replaced with another nucleotide base

data.title: Termination
data.content: The process of RNA polymerase falling off a DNA molecule at the end of transcription, allowing the two DNA strands reconnect, and the complementary RNA sequence to be free within the nucleus; it is also the process of a ribosome falling off an mRNA strand and the amino acid sequence becoming free within the cell

data.title: Thymine (T)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids, but is found only in DNA; it is classified as a pyrimidine and pairs with adenine (A)

data.title: Transcription
data.content: The process of synthesizing an mRNA sequence complementary to a DNA sequence for the purpose of synthesizing proteins

data.title: Translation
data.content: The process of reading an mRNA sequence to synthesize an amino acid sequence, and ultimately a protein

data.title: Uracil (U)
data.content: One of the five nitrogenous bases of nucleic acids, but is found only in RNA; it is classified as a pyrimidine and pairs with adenine (A)
